description.narrative: A key indicator of success will be the relative take up of the solutions and collective intelligence identified –either within policy, grafting onto UNDP programmes or through market means as independent ventures.

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Output 1: 1.1 Number of local solutions addressing key local challenges identified by the labs using new methods disaggregated by method and policy problem]; 1.2 Number of experiments undertaken by the labs; 1.3 Variation among types of experiments run by the labs Output 2: 2.1 Proportion of lead innovators (surfaced through solutions mapping) whose ideas that either a) get taken up by government or b) spin off into standalone ventures or c) influence UNDP programming [disaggregated by sex, rural urban, and country typology]; 2.2 Proportion of solutions surfaced through collective intelligence methods that either a) get taken up by government or b) spin off into standalone ventures or c) influence UNDP programming Output 3: 3.1 New models, approaches and insights from lab network documented and disseminating through working out loud; 3.2 Methods for solutions mapping, collective intelligence and experimentation developed, codified disseminated; 3.3 Proportion of solutions adapted or inspired from one country accelerator lab to another and among all UNDP country offices; 3.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the portfolio of experiments of the Accelerator Labs.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 1.1 & 1.2. 2 new sources of data per lab 1.2) 3 different data sources per Lab. 1.3) 20 new potential solutions per lab 1.4) 2 innovation methods per Action Plan
1) Digital Storytelling TOT boo-tcamp conducted to train Somali Youth on Digital storytelling 2) TOT for Future ready conducted 3) Innovation camp for Alternative energy for Household conducted 4) In 2019, the lab tested 3 innovation approaches (innovation camps, use of collective intelligence and crowdfunding). 5) The Lab helped organize 4 social innovation camps to generate home-grown ideas and solutions, and as a result 32 ideas were generated in the areas of education, environment, water and health. 6) With the Lab’s facilitation, a first ever SEED funding from private sector was provided for 2 citizens’ solutions. 7) The lab helped initiate new discussions with different UN agencies, NGOs, academia, existing innovation hubs and the private sector, thus gaining access to new data sets. 8) The lab carried out its first experimental crowdfunding capaign ‘Make every raindrop count’ with the aim to test global and local engagement in raising alternative finance for building two water catchments in two villages in Somalia that were harshly affected by drought and floods. local development projects facilitated by the UNDP environment teams, in collaboration with the local Ministries and local tribal leaders. We managed to gather funds before even launching the campaign, which is a strong indicator as to what might be possible with regards to crowdfunding as alternative financing for development projects.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1) 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. YES 2.2) At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. YES 2.3) At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. YES 2.4) At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. YES In 2019, a first ever ‘training for trainers’ was organized in Hargeisa, bringing together five top innovation hubs from Garowe, Hargeisa and Mogadishu. A total of 12 people have been trained in latest innovation methodologies such as human-centered design and mobile development platforms. In July 2019, we took representatives of the Ministry of Communication and Technology and the National Technology Institute on a study visit to Egypt, where they shared experiences and exchanged best practices with their counterparts. As a result, the Ministry of Communication and Technology is already in the process of setting up an innovation center that will help provide support to start-ups and offer courses in mobile development and advanced ICT technology. The lab tested the use of collective intelligence to identify what types of services could be provided to make life better for people with disabilities. There has been a severe lack of reliable data on young Somalis with disabilities and the few studies conducted by international organizations have called for more research and contextual understanding of the current situation. This is why we embarked on a quest to use ‘collective intelligence’ as an innovative way to gather data on the situation of persons living with disabilities in Somalia. By combining both desk research and interviews with CSOs, our study identified the main barriers to empowering people with disabilities. A specific focus of our approach is on enhancing the digital skills and employability of young Somalis with disabilities. In November 2019, the first cohort of 20 young Somali women and men with disabilities attended a two-week cyber security course on a scholarship for persons with disabilities in Egypt. They also gained new skills in areas such as e-marketing and e-commerce, which will help them become more competitive on the labor market.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1) The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network.48 interaction per year. YES 3.2) 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3) The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. NO 3.4) Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. The lab interacted with several other labs and discussed exchange of knowledge and practices. The Lab’s key highlights were captured by UNDP CO social media however not twice a month, due to other CO communication priorities as per political and security situation in the country. The lab however raised its profile by being one of the co-organizers of the Mogadishu Tech Summit and also one of the first STEM conferences in Somalia and continious exchange of information with the local innovation hubs.
1) One solution mapping for local challenge 2) One Innovation camp to address local challenge 3) Two experimentation started 4) One new partnership established

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 1.1 & 1.2.) 5 new data sources per lab 6 different data sources per lab. The lab started to source data from social media networks (twitter, Facebook and google search) to find relevant patterns in information to feed into lab and CO pilots and initiatives. In addition, to adopting both remote sensing (GIS) and high-resolution satellite imagery in our work in Data Powered Positive Deviance. The Lab adopted mini-surveys as a source of data 1.3) 35 new potential solutions per lab 38 potential solutions were collected on the topics of covid 19, waste management, alternative energy and assistive technology for hearing impaired students. 1.4) 5 innovation methods per Action Plan. In case of our water scarcity action plan the lab used Positive deviance as a method to find adaptive communities to drought and scarcity of resources. The Accelerator lab introduced Several innovation methods including hackathon, system thinking, human centered design thinking and collective intelligency.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1) At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 12 blogs have been published in 2020. 2.2) At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. More than 60% of our learning challenges involve public and private sector partnerships. 2.3) At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. NO 2.4) At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. NO
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. Yes 3.1) The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network.48 interaction per year. The Somalia AccLab had around 40 interactions with other labs in the network in 2020. 3.2) 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. YES 3.3) The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts.The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. YES 3.4) Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. YES
Other results: 1) Solution mapping exercise to identify local solution for COVID19 Conducted 2) Online Hackathon to identify Solution for COVID19 conducted and teams developed the prototype 3) Three Experimentations started on 1) Crowdfunding for COVID19 PPE kits 2) Positive Deviance 3) Early warning system for Natural disaster 4) Persons With Disability PIP project developed 5) MOU signed with SIMMAD university for joint activities 6) Youth survey conducted to identify the challenges facing youth in Somalia

1.1) 10 new data sources per lab 1.2) 9 different data sources per lab. 1.3) 50 new potential solutions per lab 1.4) 10 per Action Plan
2.1) At least 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2) At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3) At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4) At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
3.1) The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network.48 interaction per year 3.2) 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related 3.3) The Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts.The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4) Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media.
